clean_story:
Unplanned moments. Hidden patterns.


"Chance" comes from the Latin cadentia, meaning "falling"—like dice landing unpredictably.

You wake up late because your alarm fails.
A missed bus leads to a conversation with a stranger who becomes a friend.
These aren’t just accidents—they’re chance in action, reshaping routines without warning.

Science calls this the Butterfly Effect: a tiny change (a sneeze, a wrong turn) can ripple into big outcomes.
In 1961, mathematician Edward Lorenz found that rounding a decimal from . 506 to . 507 in a weather model completely altered the forecast.
Life works the same way.

Your brain even rewards chance.
Dopamine spikes when you stumble upon something good unexpectedly—like finding money in a coat pocket.
This is why slot machines are addictive: they exploit our love for unpredictable rewards.

Yet chance isn’t just luck.
It’s the gap between plans and reality.
A flat tire forces you to walk, and you notice a job posting you’d have missed.
A power outage leads to a candlelit dinner that becomes a tradition.

Probability shapes these moments.
Flip a coin 10 times—you might get 7 heads.
But flip it 1,000 times, and heads will cluster near 500.
Life’s "coincidences" often follow hidden math.

Embrace the unplanned.
The best stories start with "I didn’t mean to. .. "

Serendipity in science.
Chaos in systems.
The math of "maybe. "
